text: Counsel, you may proceed whenever you are ready.
Thank you Your Honors.
And which do you say it is?
Obviously, Your Honor our first contention is that it is a substantive jurisdictional prerequisite to suit.
Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
What would you say of neither a claim nor intent to sue notice was filed within a 180 days?
Now, I think that the 60 day notice, Your Honor, is a prerequisite.
Well, it is not what I asked you.
For an 180 days.
Well, then it is a jurisdictional provision, is it not?
I beg your pardon?
It is a jurisdictional provision then, is it not?
Well, I think you would have to consider that if you are going to apply equity, you look at all --
Well, there are some circumstances where the 180 days is jurisdictional?
Well, there has been a great deal of confusion as to what Courts call jurisdictional and --
Well, whether you call it jurisdictional or not, he is not going to get very far if he does not do something within 180 days?
Well, I would agree with that.
And you claim that this filing of claim is enough to toll 180 days?
To toll 180 days.
So then you would have the full two years given to you to bring an action in district court, once you file a complaint with the Labor Department?
Well, depending as in this case where the complaint served exactly the same purpose as a notice of intent to sue.
When would it not?
Beg your pardon?
There were several questions which were presented to Mr. Greer that I believe warrant some further discussion.
Thank you counsel.
